title: Monday, 23rd January, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Morning

PM11:00am

All you early birds

PM11:01am

Commenting as soon as the session reveals itself here

11:01 am
PM11:01am

You know I only start the session before 11am as a work around with the "new" tech

PM11:01am

If this continues will have to start thinking before we type

PM11:01am

Have some pea soup

11:01 am
PM11:02am

PM11:02am

That's from 1952

PM11:02am

The Great Smog

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Which is back, of course

undefined
PM11:02am

Trump alluded to on the right

11:03 am
PM11:03am

I was thinking we could have an alternative reality, this could be a Trump Free zone

PM11:03am

But that is difficult

PM11:03am

How do you price Trump?

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Just saying "reflation" doesnt quite capture it

PM11:03am

to my mind

PM11:04am

The guy has kicked off his presidency lying to everyone

11:03 am
PM11:04am

That's the reality

PM11:04am

How the hell you price that in to markets I have no idea

PM11:05am

FWIW JP Morgan says the Trump trade has gone fair enough

11:04 am
PM11:05am

Catch it in the LR

PM11:05am

Usual place

PM11:05am

https://ftalphavil...room/content/70975

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Good to have that back

undefined
PM11:05am

So, tin hats to hand Bryce?

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Or is that over doing it?

BE11:06am

It's a 0.5% fall FTSE wise. Yes, that's considerably overdoing it.

PM11:06am

Omg smile

11:06 am
BE11:06am

We're down 36 points. That does mean we're negative for 2017, I think, but ................ wh'evs.

BE11:07am

It can be pinned on how to live with instinctive negging and gaslighting coming from Washington, I guess, though financial markets don't usually respond to that kind of thing.

PM11:08am

gaslighting -- nice word

11:08 am
BE11:08am

We did get a trade deal update from DJT's handlers over the weekend, by the way: https://www.whiteh...king-all-americans

BE11:08am

(You may need to click past a Trump email list interstitial ad to get there.)

BE11:09am

(Because that's now what happens on virtual government property, it seems.)

11:09 am
BE11:09am

This strategy starts by withdrawing from the Trans-Pacific Partnership and making certain that any new trade deals are in the interests of American workers. President Trump is committed to renegotiating NAFTA. If our partners refuse a renegotiation that gives American workers a fair deal, then the President will give notice of the United States' intent to withdraw from NAFTA. In addition to rejecting and reworking failed trade deals, the United States will crack down on those nations that violate trade agreements and harm American workers in the process. The President will direct the Commerce Secretary to identify all trade violations and to use every tool at the federal government's disposal to end these abuses.

BE11:09am

That all sounds quite like a trade war, doesn't it?

PM11:10am

(With that link you need to continue to the website and then go back to Bryce's link)

11:10 am
BE11:10am

(@SOS: WH said yesterday he won't be releasing at all. Audit now excuse classed as irrelevant.)

BE11:11am

Anyway, we can't concentrate on that noise all session. We should move on to grittier stuff.

PM11:11am

Sure

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Flaneur mentions this Bovis - Berkeley story.

BE11:12am

Sunday Times saying Schroders (Bovis's second largest shareholder) pushing for a merger with Berk.

BE11:13am

Feltcollaredsource have allowed it to be known that Berkeley's not interested.

11:13 am
PM11:13am

This is after December's warning

PM11:13am

From Bovis

BE11:13am

Yep, and it's to be seen mostly as Schroders trying to talk its way out of a bad investment.

11:13 am
PM11:14am

ha

BE11:14am

Here's Jefferies' Anthony Codling, who's always worth reading.

BE11:14am

All the ingredients apart from the plot: Whilst a profit warning, operational issues, a CEO exiting stage left and a company trading at a 32% discount to the sector has all the ingredients for an exciting tale of M&A, it lacks in our view a credible plot.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Housebuilder M&A typically occurs when landbanks are short, but today they are long. Owned and controlled landbank lengths range from 3.7 years to 11.2 years (sector average 5.1 years) and if we include strategic land, the range is 4.7 years to 13.4 years
(sector average 10.5 years).

BE11:14am

Land market remains attractive. January trading updates across the sector consistently reported that sufficient land is available at the prices that are acceptable and if anything pricing has softened in the face of Brexit related uncertainties.

BE11:15am

Unwrapping value: At 30 June 2016 Bovis reported that the gross contribution within its owned landbank was £1.3bn, around 20% higher than its current market capitalization.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Bovis's shares currently trade at 797p (0.96x CY17 P/B), if they were to trade in-line with the sector at 1.42x the share price would be 1175p, some 47% higher than its current level.

A catalyst, a catalyst, my kingdom for a catalyst. In our view, looking at Bovis in isolation, a re-rating of the shares is unlikely ahead of the Group identifying and rectifying the operational issues and filling the empty seats at the boardroom table. However, hypothetical talk around M&A activity may lead to greater share price volatility in the short term.

PM11:15am

A fair point (on land banks) but flowery in the telling

PM11:15am

A catalyst, a catalyst, my kingdom for a catalyst.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

I like that stuff. I much prefer it to the machine-written text from the likes of Goldman.

BE11:16am

Anyway, this is Schroders trying to put Bovis in play via the Sunday Times. And kinda failing.

Bovis Homes Group PLC (BVS:LSE): Last: 822.50, up 25.5 (+3.20%), High: 841.50, Low: 819.50, Volume: 947.18k
11:16 am
BE11:16am

Shore incoming.

BE11:17am

· Why buy a business in this cycle? – there is little obvious appeal to buying another quoted house builder in this cycle primarily because there is too much land available in the open market. This means that a house builder can buy sites only where it wants to build and that it feels sit well with its brand. The changes to the planning regime under the NPPF means that there are more than 500,000 more plots of land available today than would have been in a previous cycle. New land can be bought at historically low prices and there is ample opportunity to defer payment using land creditors. None of that is possible if buying another business.

BE11:17am

· Fighting the damage already done – Bovis has had a tough time recently in the media and could have material reputational damage that could become an albatross around the neck of any bidder.

· Relationships – there appear to be deep rooted problems with sub-contractors that have been pivotal in Bovis being unable to manage build costs or deliver expected unit sales, the reason for the December profit warning. The problem with sub-contrators may also extend to professional posts across the group. If there are fractured relationships, these would be inherited by any buyer and could take a long time to unwind.

11:17 am
BE11:18am

(@CommentGoesHere: I haven't read Levine yet. What's the upshot?)

BE11:18am

Skipping a bit. Well, a lot.

BE11:18am

Paying a premium and issuing equity at a discount – if Berkeley was to make an offer for Bovis it would have to go against all the negatives and opposite actions we see from such a move plus it would have to pay a premium and issue its own equity at a discount to fund to well above £1bn price tag, perhaps more than £1.5bn EV, (Berkeley had only £208m of net cash at the interim stage and is committed to paying back 200p per share to investors through 2021). Berkeley is currently buying back its own shares as part of the capital return programme because it clearly believes that its equity is under-valued – on that basis it would be hard to imagine that it would want to issues a lot of equity at a discount to buy assets it would struggle to support or justify and that would almost certainly dilute it margins and ROCE.

11:19 am
PM11:19am

Does anyone like this idea (other than Schroders)??

BE11:20am

I think all shareholders would like the idea of Bovis rerating to be valued like a normal and functional housebuilder, perhaps by being subsumed by a ormal and functional housebuilder.

PM11:20am

Ok, but no one thinks Berkeley is dumb enough to do it

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Yep. I mean, in the same sense, I'd quite like 50% more money than I have. But I don't know how to get that. Neither, to be rude, does Schroders.

undefined
PM11:21am

We could look at Paddy Power, but that risks returning us to Trump

11:21 am
PM11:21am

http://www.investe...1701230700087845U/

PM11:21am

They "lost" the US election

PM11:22am

Or rather it was a "customer friendly" result

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Wow! A bookie saying it's lost to punters! Whatever next.

PM11:22am

Go figure

BE11:23am

And saying it lost on a binary outcome, where you'd have to have the intelligence of an unwatered cactus to screw up the arb.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

Anyway, in terms of the actual numbers .....

BE11:23am

FY EBITDA to be "around the mid-point of the previously guided
range" of £390-405m

BE11:23am

Consensus is £398m.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

Here comes Numus.

BE11:24am

FY16 and Q4 results: FY16 revenue of £1,551m (+11% in c/fx) was held back by a 70bp fall in Q4 gross win margin leading to only flat revenue in Q4 (c/fx). FY EBITDA margin of 25.6% represents +310bp yoy but only +60bp in Q4 as a result of the customer-friendly sporting results. The £40m gross impact is more than we would have thought given WMH and LAD reported c.£20m and £15m impact respectively and PPB should have benefited from its 'risk-free' betting exchange. However, it is encouraging that this was wholly mitigated through lower costs including staff and marketing savings.

BE11:24am

Q4 divisional detail: Online revenue in Q4, ex Australia (56% of group revenue) fell by 8%, compared to +20% reported in 9m16. The customer-friendly results and some weakness in gaming more than offset the 10% growth in amounts wagered (c/ fx). Australia (19% of group revenue) grew by 18% (+28% 9M16) demonstrating the benefits of geographical diversification. There was no comment regarding UK and Irish retail (19% of revenue) or the US division (6% of revenue).

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Outlook: We forecast 12% revenue growth in FY17 but 20% growth in EBITDA as operating leverage continues to support margin growth (+210bp to 27.7%). Our FY17 EBITDA forecast of £479m is 1% ahead of consensus. We do not expect any change to consensus as a result of today's announcement.

PM11:25am

Hang on, is this thing on a PE of 27 times???

PM11:25am

I must be missing something

11:25 am
BE11:25am

It is, because it's Betfair + a bookie.

PM11:25am

I know, but

BE11:25am

You need to price one at 40ish and the other at 15ish.

11:25 am
PM11:26am

I didn't realise betfair was on such a multiple

BE11:26am

22 times forward, on Numis's figures. Which doesn't look outrageous to me, as Betfair's a pretty good business.

BE11:26am

(Not investment advice.)

11:26 am
undefined
PM11:27am

Liberum Capital, what have you done

PM11:27am

http://www.investe...1701230700087842U/

11:27 am
PM11:27am

New Sports Direct broker

PM11:27am

PM11:27am

11:27 am
PM11:27am

Is this SPD normalising?

PM11:28am

PM11:28am

New chairman incoming as well soon, i nthink

11:28 am

PM11:28am

BE11:28am

11:28 am
BE11:29am

Former Army Officer in the Royal Gurkha Rifles, went to Sandhurst.

BE11:29am

I'm not 100% confident that he and Ashley will get on.

PM11:29am

Gadsby's a buyer, so that's a relief

11:29 am
PM11:29am

For him

BE11:29am

Thumbs up

PM11:29am

A buyer, but cut his target to 290p

11:29 am
PM11:29am

In december

Sports Direct International PLC (SPD:LSE): Last: 293.75, up 3.25 (+1.12%), High: 297.20, Low: 288.60, Volume: 795.34k
PM11:30am

Sorry, 310p

11:30 am
PM11:30am

We upgraded our target price on SPD to 375p this morning, in part due to better indications on corporate governance following the appointment of a new NED with strong City and investor credentials. We were disappointed to see a subsequent announcement that the company is to suspend its share buyback. Capital allocation is to be focused on acquiring freehold property. Management believes that underwriting the EBT at 300p sends a signal that it believes in the value of the business. We believe that sentiment will not be helped by suspending the buyback so revert to our previous TP of 310p.

PM11:30am

Actually, he's been pretty positive for a while

PM11:30am

Here he is last JUne

11:30 am
PM11:30am

When he last had to cut the TP

PM11:31am

Gross margin growth over the past three years suggests
that SPD has looked to support pricing and profit. In the
face of tougher market conditions we believe the company
has levers to pull. We cut estimates as we believe SPD
will invest gross margin in price to pursue the potential
upside of market share gains. We maintain our BUY rating
based on our view that the company can use its strong
balance sheet to buy back shares and significantly
enhance shareholder value. TP cut from 510p to 470p.

PM11:31am

Good luck Tom

11:31 am
PM11:31am

And good luck to the Bishop of Soho

undefined
BE11:31am

One story to mention in the weekend press.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

Well, wire rather than press. And it's US, and slightly off our usual beat.

BE11:32am

https://www.bloomb...in-strategy-review

BE11:32am

Cynosure Inc., the maker of lasers for medical and cosmetic treatments, is exploring strategic options including a sale, according to people familiar with the matter, amid increasing interest in the technology from larger global companies.

Cynosure is in talks with financial advisers as it weighs strategic options, the people said, asking not to be identified because the deliberations are private. A potential sale of the business, which has a market value of about $1 billion, may attract companies with a presence in aesthetic treatments, such as Botox maker Allergan Plc, as well as other medical-device businesses, the people said.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

A lot of punters are in this one already, and we were chasing various stories on it over recent weeks.

PM11:00am

Welcome to ML

BE11:34am

At very indicative prices of around $60 a share vs $45 undisturbed, though please remember that is merely a market rumour ....

11:34 am
BE11:35am

And do please always remember, market rumours can go horribly wrong.

PM11:35am

(ie -- you are on your own)

BE11:35am

Note Fingerprint Cards of Sweden, for instance. Story around in September about Chinese bidders ..... December profit warning .....

11:35 am
BE11:35am

And today we get .......

BE11:35am

The Swedish Economic Crime Authority has today taken Fingerprint Cards` member of the Board Lars Söderfjell into custody for alleged market abuse in conjunction with the company`s profit warning in December 2016. Also Johan Carlström, shareholder and former employee, has been taken into custody on the same grounds.

"We take very seriously on these events and the information that now has come to our attention. We are of course cooperating with the Swedish Economic Crime Authority", says Jan Wäreby, Chairman of the Board at Fingerprint Cards.

BE11:36am

Omg smile

11:35 am
undefined
PM11:36am

Extraordinary, that one

BE11:36am

There's a lot about that company that's been extraordinary over the years.

11:36 am
PM11:36am

Tho innocent till proven guilty, etc

BE11:36am

Yes. Of course. Etc.

BE11:36am

Anyway, back to sellside.

11:36 am
BE11:37am

Another Inmarsat downgrade arrives.

BE11:37am

You'll remember that the Inmarsat CFO was on a tour of analysts last week to explain the various moving parts of its 2017 numbers.

BE11:37am

There was absolutely no price-sensitive guidance given

11:37 am
BE11:38am

It was merely to help them understand the various moving parts of guidance that's already public.

PM11:38am

Yep

BE11:38am

And the fact that it's sent the shares to a three year low as consensus falls 10% or so is .... just unfortunate.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Here's Merrill's downgrade, this morning.

BE11:39am

Usual themes. More capex, less revenue certainty.

BE11:39am

11:38 am
BE11:39am

PM11:39am

Clearly, people hadn't previously been focusing on the right public information.

BE11:40am

The invisible hand approach to IR is difficult. We've written about it often with regards oil companies, which do have a lot of difficult to follow moving parts in far-off places.

11:40 am
BE11:41am

Not sure that applies to a company that makes the beep devices for fishing boats though. Whatever.

undefined
PM11:41am

Trump's up

11:41 am
PM11:41am

And trying to pretend he's normal

PM11:41am

https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/823495059010109440

PM11:41am

Actually, wider picture for a moment

11:41 am
PM11:42am

This Citi news sentiment thing just dropped into my inbox

PM11:42am

Not sure how it works

PM11:42am

11:42 am
PM11:42am

"News sentiment" fallen sharply

PM11:42am

Not sure how they measure that tho

PM11:42am

Mark Schofield is the Citi strategist

11:42 am
PM11:42am

But he doesnt explain it

PM11:43am

The recent price action in markets suggests that some of the post US election euphoria may be fading.
Our Global Macro Strategy team highlights a sharp turn in their News Sentiment Indicator that may be a precursor to a pull-back in risk appetite.
We maintain a reasonably constructive outlook on both global growth and the investing environment over the next 12-18 months but we do not think that now is the right time to be chasing risk.

PM11:43am

The reactions to both the UK Brexit vote and Donald Trump's election victory have been markedly similar. In both cases we saw initial surprise, followed by a reluctance to accept the outcome and then a striking period of exuberance, bordering on the irrational: The S&P is up almost 10% since the election and FTSE is about 20% higher than it was after the referendum. Brexiters and the pro-Trump cohort will tell you that the "experts got it wrong" while remainers and the anti-Trump lobby will say that it is "too early to tell".
We remain relatively constructive on global growth prospects for the next 12-18 months, but it is easy to have some sympathy for the "too early to tell" view. We hardly know any more about the likely shape of the UK’s EU exit than we did six months ago and there remains great uncertainty as to how many of President-elect Trump’s pre-election mandate will either be delivered or executed.
Some swings in sentiment are therefore unsurprising, particularly given the magnitude of the moves since the US election. Our Global Macro Strategy team highlights this risk in the recent turnaround in their News Sentiment Indicator. The series, which has been correlated with both risk assets and with the team's GRAMI index, has turned sharply lower (note: please see CGMS

on Bloomberg for further details.

11:43 am
PM11:43am

Warning there

undefined
BE11:44am

Request for Braemar of all things.

11:44 am
Braemar Shipping Services PLC (BMS:LSE): Last: 252.00, down 41.25 (-14.07%), High: 280.00, Low: 220.00, Volume: 311.56k
BE11:44am

Warns on profits again. Divi cut.

PM11:44am

Ouch

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Operational problems continue at the Technical division, which is suffering from lower O&G spending.

BE11:45am

Quick line from Cantor to summarise where we are.

BE11:45am

Operating profit for the full year will be in the range of £3m to £3.5m versus our forecasts for £9m (which is also consensus). The final dividend will also be cut sharply. The Group has reportedly made good progress in restructuring this division but clearly a recovery in earnings is delayed. Pending a discussion with management on the detail of the statement we place our recommendation and TP Under Review.

11:45 am
BE11:46am

Braemar issued a profit warning in late August citing weaker tanker and dry bulk broking activity, and no pick-up in project work in oil & gas technical services. Today the Group issued a further warning stating that operating profit before interest, acquisition related costs and tax for the year ended 28 February 2017 (FY17) will now be in the range of £3m to £3.5m. This is against our forecast for £9m. This excludes a one off gain before tax from disposal of Braemar’s interest in The Baltic Exchange of £1.7m and one off costs associated with restructuring of c.£2.7m. This lower forecast is largely attributed to the Technical division and in part the freight forwarding element of the Logistics business. The Shipbroking division, which is the largest part of the Group, generating over 40% of total revenue, has reportedly traded well, met its objectives and is on track to meet management expectations for the year. The Group will also cut the dividend, with a final of 5p bringing the total for the year to 14p. This is versus our forecast for a total of 23p.

BE11:46am

Weakness in the Technical division - This division has continued to underperform. The previously outlined weakness in the oil & gas sectors has worsened further with a “marked” deterioration in replacement work. Braemar has significantly expanded actions to “realign” the business. This appears to be progressing well and in time will lead to an annualised cost savings in excess of £6m. Within the smaller Logistics division, the port agency business continued to perform strongly but the freight forwarding business was affected by a reduction in market activity. Overall, the Logistics division’s performance has fallen but this will reportedly only have a small impact on overall Group results. The Group still maintains a strong balance sheet, including a net cash position at 31 December 2016 of £1.7m and an unused Group debt facility of £30m.

· Risks and target price – We view the principal risks as demand for global maritime shipbroking and technical services, acquisition execution and currency fluctuation. Our TP is derived using a 10 year DCF of net cash, this is placed Under Review from 400p.

BE11:47am

Seen nothing else there. It's only about £60-70m market cap these days so I imagine falls off a lot of coverage lists.

11:47 am
undefined
BE11:47am

Oh, Admiral ...........

Admiral Group PLC (ADM:LSE): Last: 1,727, down 6 (-0.35%), High: 1,727, Low: 1,680, Volume: 499.05k
11:48 am
BE11:48am

You'll remember there was a theory around regarding whether Admiral can stay independent post the exit of Engelhardt, its charismatic founder.

BE11:48am

Who still holds, what, 14% is it?

BE11:49am

Anyway, that was last week. As of today we get a Deutsche downgrade.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Down to sell. Partly the Ogden rate review, which we've mentioned several times now.

BE11:49am

But also the idea that self-driving cars will change the insurance industry.

BE11:49am

As in, "within a decade".

11:49 am
BE11:49am

The theory here is that accidents become fewer, but more expensive (because each prang will take out a bunch of hardware).

BE11:50am

Based on NHTSA data showing 90-95% of road traffic collisions are caused by human error, Deutsche reckons c.80% fewer accidents by 2050.

BE11:50am

And because it's the auto manufacturers that have all the data on prangs, it will make sense for them to self insure or pool to use fleet insurance or whatever.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

That's Deutsche's thesis. From there they've mapped out profit forecasts for the auto insurers to 2050.

BE11:50am

Honestly, they have. Look.

BE11:50am

11:51 am
BE11:51am

There's 28 pages of stuff about the auto insurance industry in 2050. The stuff about it in 2017 only starts on page 29.

BE11:51am

Let me get the front page.

PM11:51am

hehehe

11:51 am
BE11:51am

In this report we ask if motor insurers are losing control of their future. This seems to be the case in the long term with the emergence of autonomous vehicles (AVs), and also in the short term from the Ogden discount rate review. On the other hand, the medium-term prospects of real price increases still look supportive. On balance, with two negatives and a positive, we downgrade Admiral (ADM) to SELL. However, we maintain our BUY rating on Direct Line (DLG) due to its attractive valuation.

BE11:51am

We have extensively modelled the impact of AVs on personal motor insurers. Our work suggests profits of the UK personal motor insurers could reduce by c.80% by 2050 in our base case. Nevertheless, insurers could continue to grow for at least another 10-15 years before a meaningful impact is felt. We revise
our valuation methodology to include a long-term decline of -3% p.a. starting in 2028. This has reduced our valuations on average by 5% for the three UK motor insurers in our coverage. We highlight DLG as relatively better placed than ADM and ESUR due to a more diversified business model.

BE11:52am

Motor insurers’ earnings have been flattered for the past few years by reserve releases, which are now under pressure from temporarily higher inflation (including the introduction of the living wage) and natural normalisation. Over the medium term, however, we believe insurers can offset some of the decline in reserve releases with real price increases. Our analysis suggests that (real) pricing has not yet recovered to the level of the last peak, and for the industry’s loss ratio to improve to pre-LASPO levels, a further c.2-4ppt increase in real prices is required. The upcoming MoJ’s whiplash reforms, if successful, may reduce the absolute (not real) level of pricing, but we do not expect this reform to affect pricing for at least 12 months.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

Separately, the Lord Chancellor is expected to revise the current 2.5% discount rate used to calculate lump-sum injury awards on 31 January. We expect any reduction in this rate to lower reserve releases and have a one-off negative impact on DPS - we reflect these changes in our forecasts. In our base case, we estimate that a reduction in the discount rate to 1.5% would lower DLG’s
ongoing EPS by c.2%, with a 1.6ppt one-off reduction in 2017E yield to a still very attractive 7.5%. For ADM despite limited disclosure, we estimate an ongoing EPS impact of c.3-4% and a 1.8ppt one-off reduction in 2017E yield to a much less attractive 4.9%. Moreover, given the uncertainty around the impact of Ogden rate coupled with ADM’s c.15% valuation premium to peers, we downgrade our recommendation to Sell. ESUR may emerge as a relative winner, as the impact on EPS should be marginal but it would benefit from any potential increase in prices due to this lower rate.

BE11:52am

I mean, yeah, auto insurers will probably not be here by 2050. By historic attrition rates neither will about a third to a half of the S&P 500.

BE11:53am

I'm not convinced that's an actionable investment thesis.

11:53 am
undefined
BE11:53am

(@punter101: nope.)

BE11:53am

Also on sellside not doing much for the actual stock, but still worth mentioning .........

11:53 am
Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 256.90, down 5 (-1.91%), High: 260.50, Low: 255.40, Volume: 897.63k
PM11:54am

Go on

BE11:54am

Bruno at Bernstein's started coverage.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

His conclusion is: "Great company, crap investment."

BE11:54am

Firstly because consensus doesn't bake in that growth is expensive when you have to build warehouses ....

BE11:55am

Ocado's growth requires new CFCs, which lower utilisation & productivity in coming years. Consensus doesn’t reflect this and we are 7.6% below on EBITDA in 2017FY.

11:54 am
BE11:55am

..... and also, sales are slowing.

BE11:55am

Online food retail is nearly 20 years old in the UK and penetration has just peaked. Combined with its narrow Waitrose-style customer base, this will rapidly slow down Ocado's growth. Ocado is also very badly positioned for the most important innovations and sources of potential future growth: Click & Collect and Instantaneous Gratification online food.

BE11:55am

... and also, Ocado's valuation depends on licencing deals that it continues not to sign.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

The technology part of the business trades at 6.8X EV/Sales and 28X EV/EBITDA; Alibaba style multiples. Ocado would need to sign 1 Morrisons-sized deal per year to warrant that valuation. While we can't exclude a deal will be done, the total potential is low as there are other cheaper & lower risk options, in our view.

BE11:55am

28X EV/EBITDA!

BE11:56am

....... and also, cash is tight.

11:55 am
BE11:56am

There is no immediate liquidity risk but the lack of cash generation implies limits to its deal making capability without a rights issue or a slowdown in growth capex.

BE11:56am

So, sell.

PM11:56am

Oh yeah, what happened to that international deal

11:56 am
PM11:56am

Did i miss it?

BE11:57am

According to certain folk in the market, it's been six weeks away for approximately three years.

BE11:57am

Names come and go. They often involve a lot of Googling of regional US groceries markets. Frankly, it's been so long I've given up listening.

11:57 am
BE11:58am

So anyway, Bernstein concludes that Ocado's just a supermarket. One where you can't use its car park.

BE11:58am

Ocado has all hallmarks of being a food retailer: capital intensive, high fixed costs, low returns, limited scalability & not future proof. Its only deal, Morrisons, is becoming more troublesome.

We see 30% downside. One third of downside linked to expected earnings downgrades, the remainder to a valuation downgrade of 16X to 13X EV/EBITDA as lower growth gets reflected. Full year results on 31 January 2017 provide a first catalyst.
